channel.title: Comments on: Tokenizing filenames in SQL Server
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.content:encoded:
CLR is a good option but the memory concern is also a factor. for this, it probably wouldn’t be an issue but for thousands of executions, it could become a bottleneck.

I had something similar (although doing a few more complex processing) in place and had to revert back due to memory utilization. Although I handle it in SSIS now on a job server so memory is controlled outside of the source. (another good option)

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: Mike, CLR is a good option however a lot of shops won't enable CLR and the box that this code was running on didn't have it enabled either
item.content:encoded: Mike, CLR is a good option however a lot of shops won’t enable CLR and the box that this code was running on didn’t have it enabled either

item.title: By: Mike Blaszczak
item.dc:creator: Mike Blaszczak
item.description: Why not use a .NET user defined function? Wouldn't that be faster? Aren't applications like this entirely the point of CLR integration?
item.content:encoded: Why not use a .NET user defined function? Wouldn’t that be faster? Aren’t applications like this entirely the point of CLR integration?
